A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1974, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

A PARTY OF US WOULD OFTEN START OUT TO VISIT NEIGHBORS OR ATTEND DANCES AND END UP AT A FRIEND'S FARM HOUSE ALONG THE WAY, STRANDED FOR THE NIGHT BECAUSE OF A BAD BLIZZARD.

2. I WAS IN REGINA IN 1885 WHEN THE REIL REBELLION WAS AT ITS WORST. BEING FROM BROADVIEW I WAS ORDERED TO RETURN, AS THE C.R.B. HAD THEIR HEADQUARTERS READY FOR ALL CHILDREN AND WOMEN. WE WERE SAFE, THOUGH, AS THE INDIANS OF THE PHILIP RESERVE DID NOT CAUSE TROUBLE. AN INDIAN RUNNER BROUGHT US NEWS ALL THE TIME.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Every week or so traveled to town to trade in eggs and butter and buy groceries. We traveled eighteen miles by oxen. A very tiring journey indeed. As it took all day, there and back.

   I WAS IN REGINA IN 1885 WHEN THE REIL REBELLION WAS AT ITS WORST. BEING FROM BROADVIEW, I WAS ORDERED TO RETURN AS THE C.R.P. HAD THEIR ARMY HOUSE READY FOR ALL CHILDREN AND WOMEN. WE WERE SAFE THOUGH, AS THE INDIGENS TROUBLE, BUT PHOT RESERVE DID NOT CAUSE TROUBLE. AN INDIAN RUNNER BROUGHT US NEWS ALL THE TIME.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
